channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 August 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02666-1

The problems of political planning in 80 countries, and chemistry’s contributions to archaeology, in this week’s snippets from Nature’s archive.

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 August 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02711-z

More studies are needed on the long-term environmental consequences of war
item.dc:title: More studies are needed on the long-term environmental consequences of war

item.title: Gut microbes’ genomes are a trove of potential antibiotics
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 August 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02655-4

Newfound compound is as effective at treating infected skin wounds as is the antibiotic of last resort.
item.dc:title: Gut microbes’ genomes are a trove of potential antibiotics

item.title: The citation black market: schemes selling fake references alarm scientists
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 August 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01672-7

The ways in which researchers can artificially inflate their reference counts are growing.
item.dc:title: The citation black market: schemes selling fake references alarm scientists
item.dc:creator: Dalmeet Singh Chawla

item.title: Blow that whistle at your own risk
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 August 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02743-5

Physician scientist Nancy Olivieri describes hard-won lessons from decades of fighting for scientific integrity.
item.dc:title: Blow that whistle at your own risk
item.dc:creator: Sara Reardon

item.title: How ‘green’ electricity from wood harms the planet — and people
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 August 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02676-z

Many nations have embraced burning wood pellets to produce electricity — under the assumption that it is carbon neutral. But research shows this approach can boost greenhouse-gas emissions and threaten the health of local communities.
item.dc:title: How ‘green’ electricity from wood harms the planet — and people
item.dc:creator: Melba Newsome

item.title: How a midwife became a neuroscientist to seek a cure for her son
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 August 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02723-9

Terry Jo Bichell felt the need to work on a scientific solution to her son’s rare disorder, even though it meant being a PhD student in her fifties.
item.dc:title: How a midwife became a neuroscientist to seek a cure for her son
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Landau

item.title: How I stoked my passion for oceanography in Chile’s waters
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 August 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02682-1

Geophysicist Natalia Cisternas embarked on a 37-day voyage to document microbes in a low-oxygen region of the Pacific Ocean.
item.dc:title: How I stoked my passion for oceanography in Chile’s waters
item.dc:creator: Nikki Forrester

item.title: The Amazon is relinquishing its carbon — for a surprising reason
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 August 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02520-4

Degradation of the Amazon’s tree canopy is the main culprit, although the complete clearance of portions of the forest contributes too.
item.dc:title: The Amazon is relinquishing its carbon — for a surprising reason

item.title: These decoy ‘female’ fireflies lure males to their doom in a spider’s embrace
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 August 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02652-7

Certain spiders take advantage of the fact that a male firefly can flash even after being bitten and wrapped.
item.dc:title: These decoy ‘female’ fireflies lure males to their doom in a spider’s embrace

item.title: Gender bias might be working at level of whole disciplines
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 August 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02502-6

Study adds to growing body of evidence that such biases can affect all researchers in a field.
item.dc:title: Gender bias might be working at level of whole disciplines
item.dc:creator: Holly Else

item.title: ‘There’s a lot of privilege masquerading as merit’: why inclusion matters in academia
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 August 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02698-7

Frankie Heyward explains why he founded the National Black Postdoctoral Association, and why researchers must honestly evaluate their privilege.
item.dc:title: ‘There’s a lot of privilege masquerading as merit’: why inclusion matters in academia
item.dc:creator: Esme Hedley

item.title: Primordial black holes are too scarce to explain dark matter
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 August 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02526-y

A decades-long survey of a nearby galaxy has detected signals consistent with ancient black holes that could explain dark matter — but the objects would have to be at least ten times more abundant to support the theory.
item.dc:title: Primordial black holes are too scarce to explain dark matter
item.dc:creator: Eamonn Kerins

item.title: UK’s new science minister on budget battles, Brexit and AI leadership
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 August 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02628-7

Former clinical scientist Patrick Vallance speaks to Nature about his priorities as the minister overseeing the nation’s research.
item.dc:title: UK’s new science minister on budget battles, Brexit and AI leadership
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Gibney

item.title: Five ways the brain can age: 50,000 scans reveal possible patterns of damage
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 August 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02692-z

Results raise hopes that methods could be developed to detect the earliest stages of neurodegenerative disease.
item.dc:title: Five ways the brain can age: 50,000 scans reveal possible patterns of damage
item.dc:creator: Michael Eisenstein

item.title: PlayStation is good for you: video games improved mental health during COVID
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 August 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02643-8

But whether these findings apply more broadly remains to be seen.
item.dc:title: PlayStation is good for you: video games improved mental health during COVID
item.dc:creator: Gemma Conroy

item.title: Can floating homes make coastal communities resilient to climate risks?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 August 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02679-w

Building sustainable settlements on the water is a feasible option for climate adaptation, as long as people and ecosystems are protected.
item.dc:title: Can floating homes make coastal communities resilient to climate risks?
item.dc:creator: Idowu Ajibade
Sameer H. Shah

item.title: Cash for catching scientific errors
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 August 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02681-2

The ERROR project offers researchers a bounty for spotting mistakes in published papers — a strategy borrowed from the software industry.
item.dc:title: Cash for catching scientific errors
item.dc:creator: Julian Nowogrodzki

item.title: These labs have prepared for a big earthquake — will it be enough?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 August 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02622-z

Nature asked scientists about the measures they put in place to safeguard their research in case of disaster.
item.dc:title: These labs have prepared for a big earthquake — will it be enough?
item.dc:creator: Anna Ikarashi

item.title: Child with ultra-rare disease gets a treatment just for her
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 August 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02611-2

Therapy designed for one seems to have improved a young girl’s quality of life.
item.dc:title: Child with ultra-rare disease gets a treatment just for her

Andrew Robinson reviews five of the best science picks.

item.title: Hopes dashed for drug aimed at monkeypox virus spreading in Africa
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 August 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02694-x

Early results from clinical trial show that the antiviral drug tecovirimat is no better than placebo against the clade I virus type.
item.dc:title: Hopes dashed for drug aimed at monkeypox virus spreading in Africa
item.dc:creator: Mariana Lenharo

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 August 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02556-6

Advances in understanding the causes of the autoimmune disorder could aid in matching people with the right treatment.
item.dc:title: The mysteries of inflammatory bowel disease are being cracked — offering hope for new therapies

item.title: Jupiter mission will attempt first-ever fly-by that harnesses Earth and Moon’s gravity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 August 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02619-8

The JUICE spacecraft will slingshot around the Moon and Earth in quick succession on its way to Jupiter’s moons.
item.dc:title: Jupiter mission will attempt first-ever fly-by that harnesses Earth and Moon’s gravity
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Gibney

item.title: How to win funding to talk about your science
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 August 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02656-3

Many researchers describe public outreach as a labour of love, often carried out in their spare time. But some funders reward these activities.
item.dc:title: How to win funding to talk about your science
item.dc:creator: Hannah Docter-Loeb

item.title: Daily briefing: Stonehenge’s altar is surprisingly Scottish
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 August 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02696-9

Part of Stonehenge came from far afield, many comatose people are conscious and how ChatGPT can be most useful to scientists.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Stonehenge’s altar is surprisingly Scottish
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Dinosaur-killing Chicxulub asteroid formed in Solar System’s outer reaches
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 August 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02647-4

Rock samples hold clues to origin of impactor that sparked a mass extinction 66 million years ago.
item.dc:title: Dinosaur-killing Chicxulub asteroid formed in Solar System’s outer reaches
item.dc:creator: Michael Marshall

item.title: ‘Unacceptable’: a staggering 4.4 billion people lack safe drinking water, study finds
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 August 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02621-0

New estimate doubles the previous figure, raising questions about which is correct and highlighting gaping data holes.
item.dc:title: ‘Unacceptable’: a staggering 4.4 billion people lack safe drinking water, study finds
item.dc:creator: Alix Soliman

item.title: How I’m looking to medicine’s past to heal hurt and support peace in the Middle East
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 August 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02674-1

In this traumatized region, exploring a rich history of scientific and medical problem-solving provides the context to imagine a better future.
item.dc:title: How I’m looking to medicine’s past to heal hurt and support peace in the Middle East
item.dc:creator: Navid Madani

item.title: A Scottish origin for Stonehenge's Altar Stone
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 August 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02651-8

Geologists have found the provenance for Stonehenge's central Altar Stone, in the Orcadian Basin in Scotland
item.dc:title: A Scottish origin for Stonehenge's Altar Stone
item.dc:creator: Emily Bates

item.title: How to train your crocodile
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 August 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02610-3

Doctored toad carcasses teach crocs to avoid eating the toxin-producing cane toad.
item.dc:title: How to train your crocodile

item.title: Remodelling of the translatome controls diet and its impact on tumorigenesis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 August 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07781-7

During fasting, hepatocytes selectively remodel the translatome while global translation is downregulated, showing a new signalling property of fatty acids and that, on a ketogenic diet, treatment with eFT508 (also known as tomivosertib; a P-eIF4E inhibitor) restrains pancreatic tumour growth.
item.dc:title: Remodelling of the translatome controls diet and its impact on tumorigenesis

Davide Ruggero

item.title: Mitochondrial complex I promotes kidney cancer metastasis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 August 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07812-3

Studying changes in the metabolic properties of kidney cancer in patients reveals an increased need for mitochondrial metabolism as tumors metastasize from the kidney to distant organs.
item.dc:title: Mitochondrial complex I promotes kidney cancer metastasis

item.title: A Scottish provenance for the Altar Stone of Stonehenge
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 August 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07652-1

Mineral ages and chemical analysis of fragments of the Altar Stone from the Neolithic stone circle at Stonehenge suggest that it was transported from northeast Scotland, more than 750 km away, probably by sea.
item.dc:title: A Scottish provenance for the Altar Stone of Stonehenge
item.dc:creator: Anthony J. I. Clarke
Christopher L. Kirkland
Richard E. Bevins
Nick J. G. Pearce
Stijn Glorie
Rob A. Ixer

item.title: Molecular architecture of coronavirus double-membrane vesicle pore complex
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 August 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07817-y

A study details the molecular architecture of the double-membrane-spanning pore formed by the proteins nsp3 and nsp4 in double-membrane vesicles of SARS-CoV-2.
item.dc:title: Molecular architecture of coronavirus double-membrane vesicle pore complex
item.dc:creator: Yixin Huang
Tongyun Wang
Lijie Zhong
Wenxin Zhang
Yu Zhang
Xiulian Yu
Shuofeng Yuan
Tao Ni

item.title: Human organoids with an autologous tissue-resident immune compartment
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 August 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07791-5

We combined human intestinal immuno-organoids and single-cell transcriptomics to investigate intestinal inflammation triggered by cancer-targeting biologics, which was associated with an activated population of CD8+ T cells that progressively acquired intraepithelial and cytotoxic features.
item.dc:title: Human organoids with an autologous tissue-resident immune compartment

item.title: Structural basis for the activity of the type VII CRISPR–Cas system
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 August 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07815-0

We describe the structure and activity of Cas14 nuclease, a component of the type VII CRISPR–Cas interference complex with Cas5 and Cas7, in different functional states.
item.dc:title: Structural basis for the activity of the type VII CRISPR–Cas system

item.title: Origin and evolution of the bread wheat D genome
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 August 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07808-z

Analysis of 46 newly sequenced or re-sequenced Tausch’s goatgrass (Aegilops tauschii) accessions establishes the origin of the bread wheat (Triticum aestivum) D genome from genetically and geographically discrete Ae. tauschii subpopulations.
item.dc:title: Origin and evolution of the bread wheat D genome

item.title: Substrate binding and inhibition mechanism of norepinephrine transporter
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 August 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07810-5

Structures of human NET in the apo state and bound to meta-iodobenzylguanidine and radafaxine provide insights into the mechanism of substrate recognition and orthosteric inhibition of hNET.
item.dc:title: Substrate binding and inhibition mechanism of norepinephrine transporter
item.dc:creator: Wenming Ji
Anran Miao
Kai Liang

Yuhan Qi
Yue Zhou
Xinli Duan

Jing-Xiang Wu

item.title: Abstract representations emerge in human hippocampal neurons during inference
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 August 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07799-x

A task in which participants learned to perform inference led to the formation of hippocampal representations whose geometric properties reflected the latent structure of the task, indicating that abstract or disentangled neural representations are important for complex cognition.
item.dc:title: Abstract representations emerge in human hippocampal neurons during inference
item.dc:creator: Hristos S. Courellis

Araceli R. Cardenas

Chrystal M. Reed

Stefano Fusi
Ueli Rutishauser

item.title: Continuously fluctuating selection reveals fine granularity of adaptation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 August 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07834-x

Natural environmental and ecological shifts impose sufficiently strong selection to drive exceptionally rapid, parallel and fluctuating adaptive tracking in a Drosophila melangaster mesocosm.
item.dc:title: Continuously fluctuating selection reveals fine granularity of adaptation
item.dc:creator: M. C. Bitter
S. Berardi
H. Oken
A. Huynh
Egor Lappo
P. Schmidt
D. A. Petrov

item.title: On-chip topological beamformer for multi-link terahertz 6G to XG wireless
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 August 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07759-5

An on-chip topological beamformer for multi-link terahertz 6G to XG wireless communication achieves complete 360° azimuthal beamforming with gains of up to 20 dBi, radiating THz signals into free space with neural-network-driven customizable beams enabling up to eight simultaneous 40-Gbps wireless links.
item.dc:title: On-chip topological beamformer for multi-link terahertz 6G to XG wireless
item.dc:creator: Wenhao Wang
Yi Ji Tan
Thomas CaiWei Tan
Abhishek Kumar
Prakash Pitchappa
Pascal Szriftgiser
Guillaume Ducournau
Ranjan Singh

item.title: De novo design of allosterically switchable protein assemblies
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 August 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07813-2

We investigate the de novo design of allostery and suggest that it can arise from global coupling of the energetics of protein substructures without optimized allosteric communication pathways, providing a roadmap for the design of switchable molecular systems.
item.dc:title: De novo design of allosterically switchable protein assemblies
item.dc:creator: Arvind Pillai
Abbas Idris
Annika Philomin
Connor Weidle
Rebecca Skotheim
Philip J. Y. Leung
Adam Broerman
Cullen Demakis
Andrew J. Borst
Florian Praetorius
David Baker

item.title: Twist-assisted all-antiferromagnetic tunnel junction in the atomic limit
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 August 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07818-x

By twisting two bilayers of CrSBr, which is a 2D antiferromagnet, a >700% nonvolatile tunnelling magnetoresistance at zero field is shown, demonstrating a new strategy for constructing all-antiferromagnetic tunnel junctions down to the atomic limit.
item.dc:title: Twist-assisted all-antiferromagnetic tunnel junction in the atomic limit
item.dc:creator: Yuliang Chen
Kartik Samanta
Naafis A. Shahed
Haojie Zhang
Chi Fang
Arthur Ernst
Evgeny Y. Tsymbal
Stuart S. P. Parkin

item.title: A hot-emitter transistor based on stimulated emission of heated carriers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 August 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07785-3

A mixed-dimensional hot-emitter transistor based on mixed-dimensional graphene/germanium Schottky junctions uses stimulated emission of heated carriers, achieving an ultralow subthreshold swing and a high negative differential resistance.
item.dc:title: A hot-emitter transistor based on stimulated emission of heated carriers
item.dc:creator: Chi Liu
Xin-Zhe Wang
Cong Shen
Lai-Peng Ma
Xu-Qi Yang

Hui-Ming Cheng

item.title: Recognition and control of neutrophil extracellular trap formation by MICL
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 August 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07820-3

How MICL recognizes and autoregulates the formation of neutrophil extracellular traps is explored in mouse models and human patients where disease severity is associated with aberrant neutrophil extracellular trap formation.
item.dc:title: Recognition and control of neutrophil extracellular trap formation by MICL
item.dc:creator: Mariano Malamud
Lauren Whitehead
Alasdair McIntosh

item.title: Unimolecular net heterolysis of symmetric and homopolar σ-bonds
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 August 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07622-7

Net heterolysis of symmetric and homopolar σ-bonds by stimulated doublet–doublet electron transfer is reported in a series of atypical SN1 reactions, in which selenides show SDET-induced nucleofugalities rivalling those of more electronegative halides or diazoniums.
item.dc:title: Unimolecular net heterolysis of symmetric and homopolar σ-bonds
item.dc:creator: Anna F. Tiefel
Daniel J. Grenda
Carina Allacher
Elias Harrer
Carolin H. Nagel
Roger J. Kutta
David Hernández-Castillo
Poorva R. Narasimhamurthy
Kirsten Zeitler
Leticia González
Julia Rehbein
Patrick Nuernberger
Alexander Breder

item.title: Growth of complete ammonia oxidizers on guanidine
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 August 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07832-z

Nitrospira inopinata and probably most other comammox microorganisms can grow on the non-conventional substrate guanidine as the sole source of energy, reductant and nitrogen.
item.dc:title: Growth of complete ammonia oxidizers on guanidine
item.dc:creator: Marton Palatinszky
Craig W. Herbold
Christopher J. Sedlacek
Dominic Pühringer
Katharina Kitzinger

Michael Wagner

item.title: Precision spectroscopy on <sup>9</sup>Be overcomes limitations from nuclear structure
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 August 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07795-1

A high-precision measurement of the shielding effects of multiple electrons on the nuclear magnetic moment is made possible by spectroscopy of hydrogen-like 9Be3+, which overcomes limitations from the nuclear structure.
item.dc:title: Precision spectroscopy on <sup>9</sup>Be overcomes limitations from nuclear structure
item.dc:creator: Stefan Dickopf
Bastian Sikora
Annabelle Kaiser
Marius Müller
Stefan Ulmer
Vladimir A. Yerokhin
Zoltán Harman
Christoph H. Keitel
Andreas Mooser
Klaus Blaum

item.title: The genomes of all lungfish inform on genome expansion and tetrapod evolution
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 August 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07830-1

We find that massive genome expansion seems to be related to a reduction of PIWI-interacting RNAs and C2H2 zinc-finger and KRAB-domain protein genes that suppress transposable element expansion, and lungfish chromosomes still conservatively reflect the ur-tetrapod karyotype.
item.dc:title: The genomes of all lungfish inform on genome expansion and tetrapod evolution
item.dc:creator: Manfred Schartl

item.title: The genomic basis of childhood T-lineage acute lymphoblastic leukaemia
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 August 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07807-0

Comprehensive genomic and transcriptomics analyses of more than 1,300 cases of childhood T-lineage acute lymphoblastic leukaemia identify 15 distinct subtypes that are associated with specific outcomes.
item.dc:title: The genomic basis of childhood T-lineage acute lymphoblastic leukaemia
item.dc:creator: Petri Pölönen

item.title: Structural basis for transthiolation intermediates in the ubiquitin pathway
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 August 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07828-9

Structural analyses of analogues of stable ubiquitin transthiolation intermediates with E1, E2 and E3 enzymes reveal a population of intermediate states that provide insights into the directional transfer of ubiquitin between E1, E2 and E3.
item.dc:title: Structural basis for transthiolation intermediates in the ubiquitin pathway
item.dc:creator: Tomasz Kochańczyk
Zachary S. Hann
Michaelyn C. Lux
Avelyn Mae V. Delos Reyes
Cheng Ji
Derek S. Tan
Christopher D. Lima

item.title: Black holes regulate cool gas accretion in massive galaxies
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 August 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07821-2

Supermassive black holes regulate the amount of atomic hydrogen in galaxies and the atomic hydrogen gas mass to stellar masses ratio is more strongly correlated with black hole masses.
item.dc:title: Black holes regulate cool gas accretion in massive galaxies
item.dc:creator: Tao Wang
Ke Xu
Yuxuan Wu
Yong Shi
David Elbaz
Luis C. Ho
Zhi-Yu Zhang
Qiusheng Gu
Yijun Wang
Chenggang Shu
Feng Yuan
Xiaoyang Xia
Kai Wang

item.title: How a trove of cancer genomes could improve kids’ leukaemia treatment
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 August 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02613-0

Analysis shows that a type of fast-growing paediatric cancer has 15 distinct subtypes, each linked to responsiveness to particular therapies.
item.dc:title: How a trove of cancer genomes could improve kids’ leukaemia treatment
item.dc:creator: Giorgia Guglielmi

item.title: The mystery of Stonehenge’s central stone unearthed
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 August 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02646-5

A geochemical analysis suggests that Stonehenge’s Altar Stone came from northern Scotland — plus, chemists have finally discovered how to break selenium bonds unevenly.
item.dc:title: The mystery of Stonehenge’s central stone unearthed
item.dc:creator: Nick Petrić Howe
Dan Fox

item.title: Has your paper been used to train an AI model? Almost certainly
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 August 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02599-9

Artificial-intelligence developers are buying access to valuable data sets that contain research papers — raising uncomfortable questions about copyright.
item.dc:title: Has your paper been used to train an AI model? Almost certainly
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Gibney

item.title: What is the hottest temperature humans can survive? These labs are redefining the limit
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 August 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02422-5

The threshold for survival in heat is lower than thought — researchers are using state-of-the-art climate chambers to explore when blistering conditions threaten life.
item.dc:title: What is the hottest temperature humans can survive? These labs are redefining the limit
item.dc:creator: Carissa Wong

item.title: A virtual rat tests theories of motor control
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 August 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02592-2

How the brain controls complex movements has been a mystery. Advances in artificial intelligence now make it possible to simulate this process in virtual animals. Comparing activations in artificial control networks with brain activity in real animals enables long-standing theories of motor control at the level of neural circuits to be probed.
item.dc:title: A virtual rat tests theories of motor control

item.title: How nitrogen compounds in fertilizers and fossil-fuel emissions affect global warming
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 August 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02410-9

Human activities have led to high levels of nitrogen compounds entering the environment, causing air and ecosystem pollution. Comprehensive modelling now shows that this nitrogen has partly offset global warming — suggesting that efforts to reduce environmental nitrogen levels must be backed up with even greater efforts to mitigate climate change.
item.dc:title: How nitrogen compounds in fertilizers and fossil-fuel emissions affect global warming

item.title: Innovative way to break chemical bonds broadens horizons for making molecules
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 August 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02437-y

A fresh approach to breaking chemical bonds combines the energy of heat and light, and could drive previously inaccessible chemical reactions — opening up synthetic routes to compounds that have not yet been made.
item.dc:title: Innovative way to break chemical bonds broadens horizons for making molecules
item.dc:creator: Hannah J. Sayre
Harsh Bhatia

item.title: Geology’s biggest mystery: when did plate tectonics start to reshape Earth?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 August 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02602-3

Researchers have spent decades hunting for clues about the origins of the process that moves the continents around. Its deep history is finally starting to come into focus.
item.dc:title: Geology’s biggest mystery: when did plate tectonics start to reshape Earth?
item.dc:creator: Michael Marshall

item.title: Chatbots in science: What can ChatGPT do for you?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 August 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02630-z

Milton Pividori spent a year and a half studying how best to use ChatGPT in research. Here, he highlights three key lessons.
item.dc:title: Chatbots in science: What can ChatGPT do for you?
item.dc:creator: Milton Pividori

item.title: One-quarter of unresponsive people with brain injuries are conscious
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 August 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02614-z

More people than we thought who are in comas or similar states can hear what is happening around them, a study shows.
item.dc:title: One-quarter of unresponsive people with brain injuries are conscious
item.dc:creator: Julian Nowogrodzki

item.title: The Taliban said women could study — three years on they still can’t
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 August 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02626-9

Afghanistan is the only country in the world that stops its girls and women from attending schools and universities. And the Taliban show no sign of changing that.
item.dc:title: The Taliban said women could study — three years on they still can’t
item.dc:creator: Miryam Naddaf

item.title: How the human brain creates cognitive maps of related concepts
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 August 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02433-2

Neural activity in human brains rapidly restructures to reflect hidden relationships needed to adapt to a changing environment. Surprisingly, trial-and-error learning and verbal instruction induce similar changes.
item.dc:title: How the human brain creates cognitive maps of related concepts
item.dc:creator: Mitchell Ostrow
Ila Fiete

item.title: Stonehenge’s enigmatic centre stone was hauled 800 kilometres from Scotland
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 August 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02584-2

By assessing the age of ancient crystals, researchers have traced the monument’s greenish Altar Stone to a northern rock basin.
item.dc:title: Stonehenge’s enigmatic centre stone was hauled 800 kilometres from Scotland
item.dc:creator: Nisha Gaind
Roff Smith
